website_summaries.verdict: These batteries wowed users and held up in performance to non-rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, despite their lower price.
pros: Offering lower cost than competitors, these batteries are noted for maintaining their charge
cons: A few customers note they didn't last or recharge well, but this seemed like an atypical experience

customer_reviews.title: I am very disappoint to report that 3 of my 16 pack have ...
customer_reviews.text: I bought a pack of the black ones back in April 2016. I am very disappoint to report that 3 of my 16 pack have leaked in my Nikon Speedlight SB-700 flash. It almost ruined my brand new flash. Now I question whether to trust the other 13. I will be contacting Amazon to let them know about there faulty product. I also have the more expensive grey and they seem to work fine. Not sure if I just got a bad set.
customer_reviews.author: Danielle

customer_reviews.title: This was a huge waste of money
customer_reviews.text: Everytime I take a dead battery out of an item I put them back into the charger, charge them to full capacity, and then store them. Every time I go back to the box to get a new one out they're dead again and I have to end up buying disposables. This was a huge waste of money. I tried to replace all my batteries with rechargeable batteries and just ended up spending ridiculous amounts of money on batteries that don't hold a charge.
customer_reviews.author: KLM

customer_reviews.title: JUNK AVOID. MANY STOP WORKING AFTER SEVERAL MONTHS
customer_reviews.text: Pure Junk. Order several sets of those. Not heavy user in toys, etc. Just regular use in remotes thermostats, etc. Some batteries just get disconnected internally. You put them in the charger, good one, and nothing. Got replacement for some units from Amazon, some of the replacement stopped working too. Just not worth the hassle
customer_reviews.author: vexas

customer_reviews.title: Not so good!
customer_reviews.text: As anything new, work great at first. Noticed that it lost charge. Had them almost 2 months and began to leak. Guess what, called Amazon. The batteries only had a 30 day return policy so after less than 2 months, nothing I or Amazon representative can do about it (outside the 30 day window), so no return or exchange! Any other company would have warrantied their product much longer. Disappointing. Maybe spending more and get a Sanyo Eneloop is the next step.
customer_reviews.author: CC

customer_reviews.title: Item has changed!
customer_reviews.text: My previous order of AmazonBasics AAA Rechargeable Batteries were made in Japan and probably equivalent to Eneloop AAAs. These are made in China. This is not listed in the description, but can be found in the reviews, which I looked at more carefully after receiving these batteries. I have returned this order.
customer_reviews.author: Lee R.

customer_reviews.title: Good lord they are aweful
customer_reviews.text: Horrible I took them on a camping trip and I wouldnt trust them if I was wild camping...they lose power really fast and take a while to charge...my headlamp went out after 2 long uses and with regular batteries I could have gotten at least 4 days of continuous use..pay a bit more and get a better product..now I have to return them..These werent made for serious users...probably good for your kids toys they dont play with that often but serious users in a serious situation I do NOT recommend them
customer_reviews.author: Rez jr

customer_reviews.title: Constantly have to be recharged, not worth it
customer_reviews.text: With old non-rechargeable batteries my Comcast remote would work for 1-2 years. In the past 2 months that I've had these, I've had to recharge the batteries in my remote 3 times!! The kids' toys also have these and constantly need to be recharged. Very disappointed, these simply don't keep a charge. 1 star.
customer_reviews.author: Justin

customer_reviews.title: Wasteful Packaging
customer_reviews.text: The point of using rechargeable batteries is to reduce waste. 4 batteries, preciously packaged in box that is big enough to hold 48 is excessive. It is counterproductive to people who are trying to be green.
customer_reviews.author: Cherrie

customer_reviews.title: 25% failure rate
customer_reviews.text: Out of the 8 batteries, 2 are now bad after only being recharged a couple of times. Description states battery will hold charge for 3 years, but it only has a one year warranty. Now they've failed out of warranty, how do I get my other 2 years? Would have been better off buying a couple of alkalines from Big Lots.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew

customer_reviews.title: Great for people that love to change batteries often!
customer_reviews.text: I ordered the AAA and AA batteries and the AmazonBasics charger. They are a disappointment. Freshly charged batteries just don't last very long. Maybe my expectations were unrealistic: I hoped they would last as long as a disposable Energizer or Duracell. After 2 months of using them I've come to the conclusion that I've wasted my money. I guess it's possible the charger is not fully charging the batteries, or maybe the batteries are just crap. Regardless, I just bought a fresh pack of Energizer disposable batteries because I'm not one of those people who live to swap batteries.
customer_reviews.author: Clever User Name

customer_reviews.title: One use!
customer_reviews.text: 90% of my batteries won't recharge. Using original Amazon Basics charger, the led's just flash red. They appeared to be charged on delivery, used them in candles, then went to recharge and they won't. My guess is that they can't be run down to full dead like a candle can do. That is my only guess. But I'm not going to charge them when the candles are still lit... Costco batteries it is, hate to dispose of regular batteries, but screw it. These are not reliable.
customer_reviews.author: Magyver

customer_reviews.title: horrible. they don't hold even a tenth of the ...
customer_reviews.text: horrible. they don't hold even a tenth of the power the older amazon basics batteries i bought do. i have to change these out in a wireless mouse continually. when the old batteries i have last months. these are garbage
customer_reviews.author: Micha S

customer_reviews.title: Good luck finding a better re-chargeable and a better price
customer_reviews.text: I love these batteries and I love that Amazon keeps changing the printing on the casing so I can just about tell which year I purchased reinforcements. ;) The only downside is that these batteries aren't great for slow-drain applications like smoke detectors, thermostats and wireless mice. Much better, however for quick use and recharge, like camera flash and children's toys. In all applications I find that a non-rechargeable battery would perform slightly better/longer, however, to save the planet, these batteries are perfect for all but the most demanding, critical applications. I'm going into my 6th year using my first batch of these batteries so long term storage and re-use have definitely saved me money.
customer_reviews.author: Clark

customer_reviews.title: No longer Japanese cells
customer_reviews.text: The black label Basics no longer use Japanese cells. The capacity and origin are now the same as the white label, 800mAh and made in China. Doesn't mean they're bad, but I was expecting the same batteries I ordered a year or so ago.
customer_reviews.author: Ben Drexl

customer_reviews.title: Pay a little more for better quality
customer_reviews.text: Hardly used these over three years, but at least half of them won't charge now. Spend the the little extra and get the Eneloops or any other brand that is highly rated by experts. Made in China says it all! Sourcing may have changed since I purchased these, but I'd still be skeptical if they aren't made by Panasonic (the Eneloop manufacturer).
customer_reviews.author: Texas Surfer

customer_reviews.title: Basically a good deal . . .
customer_reviews.text: Reviewing 12-pack of AAA, received August 2018, white with thin green ring at the top, made in China . . . all but two test between 800 and 850 mah (the two were 790-800), easily meeting the "750mah minimum" listing and consistent with "800mah" on the cells. Can't speak to longevity (obviously), but the out-of-box performance/capacity matches the much more expensive Eneloop cells already owned. Even if they only last 100 cycles (instead of the claimed 1000) that's a penny-a-use, and most will be lost or "borrowed" long before that.
customer_reviews.author: Deward Hastings

customer_reviews.title: Very Good Battery for Not a Lot of Cash
customer_reviews.text: I am using battery in a low drain shortwave radio. They are holding charge well and test at around 2100mah capacity. I ran them through the break-in charge procedure on a Maha MH-C9000 charger. The break-in charge/dis-charge cycles are 39 hrs in length being very gentle on the batteries. I then did a charge/discharge/charge and recorded battery date, group and capacity. Did this with first 8 batteries and they were all very close in capacity. I grouped the most similar into 2 different groups. Put the first group into use over a week ago in my shortwave and they are doing fine-still shows full charge on radio @ NiMH voltage setting.
customer_reviews.author: Slam

customer_reviews.title: What can you say about rechargeable batteries, they bring me joy
customer_reviews.text: It’s not often you could say batteries bring you joy , but these batteries leave my rechargeable solar lights for my walking area and backyard plants illuminated well into the night and they still are on at 3 o’clock in the morning. As old men do, I often get up at nite, go look in my backyard to take the time and find the joy in small things, such as a beautiful night in paradise, illuminated by these batteries and then write a review.
customer_reviews.author: Steve Anton

customer_reviews.title: Garbage, don’t waste your money
customer_reviews.text: These batteries are trash. They were charged and used one time in a label printer and only 2 of them will even take a charge now. The product manager for this item should be fired.
customer_reviews.author: Minkbinkmini

customer_reviews.title: Chinease
customer_reviews.text: Have now re-ordered new replacements of (8/2019) both the "Black" case, Capacity: 2000mAh (milliamp-hour) Minimum 1900mAh and the "White" case 2,000 mAh rechargeable AA batteries. Both are now made in CHINA! No more Amazon option to Eneloop. Seems Amazon choose profit over reliability. I have ordered them in the past and they were from Japan manufacturing and had quality same as Eneloop.
customer_reviews.author: IFISHAZ

customer_reviews.title: Drain quickly with no load
customer_reviews.text: The Amazon Basics High Capacity AA rechargeables are great....the standard ones are not. I fully charged these, put them in a deadbolt lock and less than a day later (with no use of the lock) I was getting a low battery warning. Note this was the last of 8 locks I installed and others have been in place for months with the same rechargeable batteries. I had also purchased the Amazon Basics High Capacity AA rechargeables and they are working out great. These may work in some applications but clearly not for mechanized door locks.
customer_reviews.author: Bob M

customer_reviews.title: Reliable. Perform well. Slow discharge.
customer_reviews.text: I own over 2 dozen handheld radios that require AA batteries. I've been using AmazonBasics AA Rechargeable Batteries in them instead of "Eneloops" for quite some time now since they're less expensive. I find that the AmazonBasics batteries work equally as well. They've been reliable and don't go dead even after months of non-use. Unlike some of the cheap off the wall brands of AA rechargable batteries that make silly claims on their capacity, as per my battery analyzer/charger AmazonBasics AA Rechargeable Batteries always provide around their stated 2,000 mAh capacity. I've also yet to have one fail prematurely or arrive DOA. These are good batteries at a fair price.
customer_reviews.author: DLH

customer_reviews.title: Doesnt last as long as a disposable battery
customer_reviews.text: Doesn't hold a charge very long charged them and put in and died soon after. Disposable batteries lasted two weeks these lasted two hours.. installed into a baby swing
customer_reviews.author: Bailey

customer_reviews.title: Over the 5000 mah rating
customer_reviews.text: Out of the box tested to near 10% OVER capacity. Very happy with these. I will comeback and update if they fail to maintain such great capacity but I really seem to doubt I will have problems.
customer_reviews.author: JIm

customer_reviews.title: Do not buy for important electronics
customer_reviews.text: Do not purchase these for anything important. They are fine for remote controls, or maybe a toy car, but not for anything safety related. I got these for flashlights, headlamps, GPS, and other essential camping gear in order to cut down on battery waste. As you can see from the photo, the terminal is shorter than a standard battery and will not always make contact. This is the case for ALL of the batteries. Thankfully I checked before I went on my trip, but will only use these for around the house. Very disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: adam

customer_reviews.title: I should have ditched my alkalines long ago
customer_reviews.text: These have been going strong for quite some time. I tend to use them in low drain devices over long periods of time (wall clocks, remote controls, mice/keyboards, etc) and all are still working well. I have more than I need, so when one finally runs out, I drop it in the "recharge pile" and then grab one from the "fresh pile". When my fresh pile is getting low, I recharge everything on the recharge pile and they live their lives in labeled cases so I know which is which. I'm a bit nerdy like this, but I fell much better than running through non-rechargable batteries.
customer_reviews.author: Kevin G.

customer_reviews.title: Not made in Japan as I had thought
customer_reviews.text: I was under the impression that these cells were made in Japan. As another reviewer has stated, they switched to cells made in China at some point in 2019. Mine (black wrapper) were manufactured June 2019 and made in China. I am disappointed in this fact. However, some reviews show that they do live up to their mah rating and appear to be (hopefully) decent quality cells. I cannot test their capacity with my charger unfortunately, so I'll just have to settle and trust that these are okay.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew J.

customer_reviews.title: Made in China October 22nd 2019.
customer_reviews.text: Was looking forward to Japanese made batteries only to find that they are made in china as of October 22nd 2019. I'm not confident in the quality of these batteries to last or have the expected shelf life. if you want decent batteries you should buy from a trusted manufacturer that specializes in batteries.
customer_reviews.author: Master Shake

customer_reviews.title: Advertised as Made In Japan; Sent the cheapo Made In China variety
customer_reviews.text: I bought these because people have said they are rebranded Japanese cells that last a really long time - but ONLY if you get the ones with black trim on the top. That was my experience in the past too. They worked. However this time despite this listing explicitly showing the Made In Japan version in the pictures, I was sent the Made In China version with white trim. We'll see how long they last.
customer_reviews.author: Sebastian Xavier

customer_reviews.title: Don’t hold a charge - not pre-charged
customer_reviews.text: These do not hold a charge. You have to have them constantly on a charger and take them directly from there for them to even work. Even when doing that, they have no capacity to run kids toys or anything that needs normal power. I put 2 fully charged ones in a basic temperature/humidity sensor and the screen showed the battery as low (1 of 3 bars). So they’re not even sufficient to power something requiring minimal power like that, a thermostat or remote. Will not buy again and consider this purchase a complete waste of money. These will be in the garbage shortly. Spend the extra money and get Eneloops.
customer_reviews.author: K. Hanson

customer_reviews.title: Quick to fail
customer_reviews.text: After a few charges and uses, the batteries leaked inside my camera bag. A red/orange sticky substance remained in the pocket where the batteries were stored. Two batteries from this order are clearly faulty. These batteries are used casually for electronic devices at home, and I don't believe they should fail so quickly. The other items inside the pocket were also damaged by these bad batteries.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer NYC

customer_reviews.title: IT"S NOT FROM JAPANN, IT"S CHINA GUYS, after 8 days it died
customer_reviews.text: I hope they are good because it was supposed to be from Japan which I read from Japan are the good ones, When I opened the box, I saw not Japan but CHina which I doubt it's the same quality. I'll keep updating this review when I test them more... Update I fully charged my batteries and it lasted only for 8 days, so I have to comeback and charge it again. This time I still have time to return but I'll give one more chance to these batteries!
customer_reviews.author: Vlad

customer_reviews.title: Made in China
customer_reviews.text: Amazon did not send me the rechargeable batteries that are made in Japan. I received the Chinese knockoffs. These are well known to not hold a charge, and only last a fraction of the advertised number of charge cycles.
customer_reviews.author: Shiro

customer_reviews.title: Made in China
customer_reviews.text: I was hoping for the made in Japan version, but these are definitely labelled made in China. AAA 8 pack purchased Sept 2019 ASIN B00CWNMXQW

customer_reviews.title: As of December 2019, Made in China
customer_reviews.text: Not Rebadged Eneloops. :( I have put one on my new Opus tester and it came out at 845 mAh, which isn't bad. I'll be testing all of them and report back as to the average capacity and also lifespan. This compares with a several year old Eneloop that tested out at 771 mAh. Still quite disappointed they aren't Japanese. Amazon should update the picture to reflect the Chinese source.
customer_reviews.author: Stephanie Anglemyer

customer_reviews.title: They seem to be the real deal for a great price
customer_reviews.text: I haven't had a chance to put them to a real test, but they do feel a lot more dense and heavier than those other brands. I have both D's and C's rechargeables and I would guess the mah claims are pretty close to accurate. I didnt do a full discharge test but they were about 50% charged when I got them and my Xtar dragon charger said it put about 5000mah into the d cell. I ran them in a 3-D maglite with an 800lumen drop in kit and they worked fine. I plan to get a lantern to run them in as well.
customer_reviews.author: Tyler

customer_reviews.title: dont hold a charge
customer_reviews.text: this is another example of cheap rebranded Chinese junk. all the reviews I read stated these were eneloop rebranded made in japan quality batteries. when I received these clearly stated on package made in china. I bought these for my vr controllers and they only lasted 1.5 hours before the low battery warning. these are garbage and ill be returning these for real made In japan quality batteries.
customer_reviews.author: loucarisma

customer_reviews.title: Great for 5 or 6 years of use!
customer_reviews.text: I got a ton of use out of these! So... lately when I put them into recharge, the readout says "defect" and they won't recharge at all. One by one over the last year, each battery has suffered the same fate. And I'm not complaining! I've used them in clocks, flashlights, LED disc lights to illuminate the closet, remotes and toothbrushes. And they've been recharged dozens and dozens of times. Who knows how many disposable batteries I didnt have to buy over the past five years or so! Mine were white, btw, and were purchased in fall of 2013.
customer_reviews.author: BlueSkyFine

customer_reviews.title: Flat in a very short amount of time - and in less than a year not able to be recharged
customer_reviews.text: I installed these in a Duracell LED flashlight, which worked fine at first, but only a month later, without having been used in the meantime, it was totally dead. I checked each cell with a multimeter and found that every one showed a *negative* charge of a few mV. I have now recharged them, and they seem to be OK again. Time will tell how long they retain their charge. The flashlight in which they were installed was dead again despite having had little or no use, and when I tried to charge them I got an error message. I'm just within the 1-year warranty period, and I am getting a full refund. Customer Support was great.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: WTH? These are not 1.5V batteries !
customer_reviews.text: It seemed strange to me when I started to use them that the devices sounded week as if the batteries were not fully charged. I charged them overnight and after measuring with a voltmeter it showed around 1.32V. I have been thinking that my charger went broke until I checked the batteries label. They are 1.2V instead of 1.5V !! This is the first time I see AA batteries not being 1.5V. I now have checked several devices and all state to use AA 1.5V batteries so not sure where are these batteries intended to be. I've reviewed again the Item description and the voltage is not stated anywhere. Disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: Wtech

customer_reviews.title: The batteries rusted within 2 months of use as shown in the photo
customer_reviews.text: I put these in my Automatic trash bin. After a few weeks it started acting up. I could not imagine the batteries could be the culprit. I inspected the batteries and they were all rusted. These are supposed to be rechargeable batteries. If they rust within 2 months, what is the point? Amazon customer service gave me a real hard time getting refund as I didn't want a replacement of this crappy product. Do not recommend.
customer_reviews.author: YS

customer_reviews.title: Just horrible.
customer_reviews.text: These hold a charge for less than a day, where other brands in the same device will work for weeks. Whether they're not charging all the way (they report being 94% charged), or what, I can't tell, but they're certainly not working right. 94% to 2% in less than 24 hours of use in my mouse? I've used at least 6 other rechargeable brands in my mouse and gotten months of use before needing replacement. Just horrible.
customer_reviews.author: espd

customer_reviews.title: Not Good
customer_reviews.text: The batteries held a charge for a couple of cycles. Four would run a small desk fan for 8 hours at first. Then, I needed to change the batteries once during a work shift after a week. It’s been three or four weeks since purchase, and the entire pack of 16 batteries are now required to get through the same 8 hour shift. I remember rechargeable batteries back in the 80s for a gameboy that lasted continually until the batteries were lost (a couple of years). These amazon batteries were designed to make the customer keep buying, but regular AAs are cheaper at this rate.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good value, good power, sizing is off slightly
customer_reviews.text: Overall I'm happy with these. I've found that they are just SLIGHTLY oversize (thickness, not length), at least the ones I received. For some things, it's fine, but for certain devices where the batteries are completely contained in some sort of sleeve (like some flashlights), the batteries don't slide out on their own, and I have to tap the device a couple times to get them out. All other batteries (alkaline and rechargeable) I've tried in the same devices fit fine. Again, not a deal breaker, but I've never had a battery before that wasn't 100% perfect on sizing.
customer_reviews.author: JLaker

customer_reviews.title: Arrived dead, all 8!
customer_reviews.text: I am not happy at all that the batteries arrived completely dead! I mean I understand that they are rechargeable batteries, but you would think they would at least arrive fully charged, so I had to charge every single battery, before I could use them! So we’re going to see how long they actually last before I had to charge them again. Do better!
customer_reviews.author: Chrys Mims

customer_reviews.title: Received "old stock" white ones from China.  Last year I got 'made in Japan' ones
customer_reviews.text: I wish Amazon would specify whether you're getting the Panasonic/Japanese rebranded ones versus the white Chinese ones. Last year I bought Amazon Basics AA rechargeables and they are black with a green tip. These are the good ones made in Japan. These white ones with a green tip are made in China. Nowhere near the battery life/quality of the Japanese ones. I'll keep these because they are still a decent price. Just wish Amazon wouldn't bait and switch so much.
customer_reviews.author: JD

customer_reviews.title: Batteries are made in China
customer_reviews.text: I just ordered some C-Cell batteries as the listing photo shows the black and green batteries, which others have confirmed are similar to Sanyo/Eneloop and are made in Japan. The batteries I received are grey and green and are made in China. I have no idea how these perform yet and will update my review as I use them. I just thought others should know the current version is different than shown in the photo.
customer_reviews.author: woodie

customer_reviews.title: made in china
customer_reviews.text: Just got them, so can't really judge them, but not being able to figure out before buying where they were made was frustrating. I had bought some of the "white label" Amazon Basics a few years ago that were made in Japan, and have been very happy with them. That's what I thought I was buying again this time, but I guess not. I'll try to update as these get used to see if they last, hold a charge, etc.
customer_reviews.author: Vicki

customer_reviews.title: How can batteries be this bad?
customer_reviews.text: I've been using Panasonic Eneloop batteries for years and they continue to work, after hundreds of charges. But for some reason decided to save a couple dollars this time and get the Amazon AAA batteries, and they stopped working within the first few charges. How is that even possible? I have the advanced Eneloop charger that blinks red when batteries have gone bad, and half my batch of Amazon AAA batteries have now gone bad. Stay away.
customer_reviews.author: Slavik Boyechko

customer_reviews.title: These are the only batteries I buy now
customer_reviews.text: I have already purchased the AAA and they worked so well I decided to buy the AA version. I love these batteries not only because they are rechargeable but because they last forever. I haven't had one battery crap out on me yet and I don't believe they will if kept in good condition and stored properly. I only wish they came with a storage case for when I'm not using them. If you have a lot of devices that take batteries these are definitely a good buy.
customer_reviews.author: SakuraHana

customer_reviews.title: Don't waste your money
customer_reviews.text: Very disappointed in this product. After reading several reviews I thought these were good batteries. I was sadly mistaken. We have several outdoor lights. We replaced the batteries for the lights on our flag pole and they only lasted 2 days. They receive several hours of direct sunlight every day to recharge and should be able to power the LED lights all night, night but they don't. The batteries only lasted one night on our patio solar lights. They are completely out in just a few hours.
customer_reviews.author: Tonya Lowery

customer_reviews.title: Don't buy rechargeable batteries - they still suck
customer_reviews.text: They work pretty great on their first charge, but that's it. After that, they can't even hold a charge sitting in a drawer. And my complaint is against ALL rechargeable batteries, not just these. For example, I even tried the SUPER expensive Energizer, and they have the same performance after the first charge, and the first charge doesn't last as long as you would hope or expect. If you enjoy a battery-changing hassle reminiscent of 1990's technology, go ahead and buy these things. However, if what you want is batteries that last longer than about 4 weeks, just buy regular, non-rechargeable batteries. That's the route I'm taking after trying these things for several years. I'm simply tired of it.
customer_reviews.author: F. Tate

customer_reviews.title: Bait and Switch
customer_reviews.text: Amazon sells various versions of rechargeable batteries under the same product name. Previous ones I've bought where all white and were made in Japan. The last purchase I got were white with green on each end and are made in Japan. The MAH is listed the same but I put a set in two different battery operated candles and my old batteries lasted well over an hour longer. I'll go back to spending a little more on actual eneloops and now Chinese Amazon garbage.
customer_reviews.author: Scott B.

customer_reviews.title: Stay Away! Multiple Dead on Arrival!
customer_reviews.text: I've used rechargeable for years. Typically from brands such as Energizer. These are the worst rechargeables I have ever had. I have ordered this specific product (12 pack) three separate times and only a small handful of them still work. The issue is they do not charge after they are used once. I am using the Amazon charging base and it still does not work. I read the instructions and followed it perfectly. Amazon is ripping people off on this one. I will be requesting a full refund.
customer_reviews.author: Patrick

customer_reviews.title: Not good, not good at all
customer_reviews.text: Within a year, these (black-topped) batteries fail to hold any appreciable charge. I use a La Crosse BC-700 charger, and even refreshing these batteries does not help. Used mainly in game controllers, after they are "fully" charged, they don't last more than 20 minutes or so. These batteries allegedly used to be great, but apparently their popularity has led to quality cuts at the factory, because these are *not* quality batteries. Useless within a year, would have been cheaper just to buy eneloops to begin with.
customer_reviews.author: alexbravo

customer_reviews.title: Not nearly what they are cracked up to be.
customer_reviews.text: I was tempted by the reviews that stated these are great batteries. The lithium chemistry was attractive to me for being able to have numerous cycles or recharges. I expected the performance of these batteries to be better than alkaline batteries. Not so. After a full charge, I get about four hours use before they tank, using my Eveready LED headlamp. Fresh alkaline batteries stay strong for over six hours and trail off the voltage slowly. These lithium batteries come on strong but burn like a rocket. They are no better than alkaline batteries, in my experience. Best to consider the Panasonic lithium batteries as the published performance is more reliable than these cheap imports.
customer_reviews.author: David A. Albright

customer_reviews.title: Why not 5 star?
customer_reviews.text: Old version amazon basic was much better. ... not only better, they was excellent (made in japan). New green amazon basic accumulators are made in china.
customer_reviews.author: Joseph

customer_reviews.title: Disappointing
customer_reviews.text: I really had high hopes for these batteries. The reviews and ratings were just amazing, so I had to give them a try. The main purpose for these batteries has been to keep a little nightlight on in my daughter’s room. And for the first week it was great, they lasted two nights. Now I’m lucky if they keep the light fully bright one night. A lot of the time they dim after a few hours. It’s really ridiculous. I’m so sad and disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: BLand

customer_reviews.title: They're OK, not great.
customer_reviews.text: They are inexpensive. They work. That's why I own several sets in different sizes. Just know they aren't the greatest. They don't hold a charge as long as premium brand rechargeables. And they seem degrade more quickly (doesn't last as many recharge cycles). That said, we use them to power the kids' toys so it hardly matters. An inexpensive rechargeable battery is all we needed. If you really needed a very good battery you can depend on; spend more and get better batteries. This is not the battery you'd bet your life on heading down into a cave or something like that.
customer_reviews.author: Elizabeth

customer_reviews.title: I'm impressed
customer_reviews.text: I used these to replace two year old 600 mah NiMh batteries that came with some solar pathway lights. The original batteries would be exhausted by midnight, even when new. These new batteries keep the lights on all night until dawn. My lights are having no problem charging these batteries. These batteries are noticeably heavier than the original batteries that came with the lights. I can't speak to longevity. I'm expecting they will last a couple of years.
customer_reviews.author: DouginNC

customer_reviews.title: Works just like Eneloops but cheaper
customer_reviews.text: For vast majority of consumers, you won't be able to tell the difference between these and their much pricier cousins, Eneloops. When on sale, these go for less than half the price, and give you probably 90% the performance and longevity. It's a no brainer, get these instead. Pro-tip: These are great for electronics or toys which you hardly use since they keep the charge for a many months. Also, they don't leak so you don't run the risk of battery juice destroying your electronics. Pro-pro-tip: Ikea also sells an excellent similar rechargeable battery. Price compare and get whichever is cheaper, they are all amazing batteries.
customer_reviews.author: PRIME

customer_reviews.title: Great batteries if they fit
customer_reviews.text: Aaa batteries are good. The aa batteries that I also ordered work good, but are oversize so they dont fit in some of the things that i use them or would use them in. About a year ago I ordered 2 sets of the aa batteries, one set worked great, no problem in anything that I put them in. The second set were oversized to, dont fit in a lot of things. The ones that fit everything had thin green band on one end. The oversize ones had a wider green band on one end. I also ordered Tenergy aa batteries, and they are oversize to. Looks like some of the batteries made in China are made a little oversize.
customer_reviews.author: DI

customer_reviews.title: Can be stored long term
customer_reviews.text: This product is amazingly well made. I've had rechargeable batteries before that were also Ni-MH from a cheaper brand but they do not last long. (only a few months) I only needed two of these and I used them for about 5 years until I lost them. Then I realized I have completely ruined my spare batteries, because I kept them in a box in a shelf for all those 5 years without charging them. I put them in my calculator, and it still works! Wow am I surprised. Did I mention I didn't even charge them? Usually rechargeable batteries would die from a year of inactivity, let alone 5.
customer_reviews.author: John M.

customer_reviews.title: Great for outdoor solar lighting
customer_reviews.text: My outdoor solar lights would only stay on for an hour each evening. Opened the light and found they were a single AA 1.2 volt 500 Mah NI-Cd battery. After some research I decided to purchase 2000 Mah AA replacement batteries. What a DIFFERENCE they now run the entire night and turn off at dawn. Impressive I was going to trash the lights I had no idea that the solar rechargeable battery could be replaced so easily. I’ve only had them a few days so I’ll update the review later for their longevity but so far I’m very satisfied. I’m also interested to see how they do on cloudy days.
customer_reviews.author: AmazonCustomer

customer_reviews.title: Amazon Basics AAA 800mAh (made 9/2019)
customer_reviews.text: I haven't run them much yet but thought to get a preliminary review going to say my AAA's are indeed made in China. Manufacture date 9/2019. These may be relegated to use in my TV remotes.
customer_reviews.author: Schwartz

customer_reviews.title: Don't hold a charge
customer_reviews.text: arrived as "pre charged", put them on the charger anyways. At "fully charged" they don't work for longer than maybe 6 hours tops before they need to be charged again. Was trying to get away from having to buy batteries every few months, but at this rate - it's cheaper to continue buying bulk non rechargeable batteries, or at least buy name brand batteries that will last longer.
customer_reviews.author: Bruce W.

customer_reviews.title: C Cells work great in Tektronix THS720A oscilloscope !!
customer_reviews.text: I rebuilt the original Tektronix stick pack that consisted of 4 c cells. The scope runs well over 3 hours on a charge. Very happy about that !! The cells had to be spot welded to each other, just like the original cells were. These AmazonBasics C cells are button tops so they are a little longer than the flat top cells the stick pack came with. Including the nickel strips used for spot welding the new pack is longer, but just fits into the scope. The price for these cells varies daily from $10 to $12. Just bought a second set of 4, to rebuild another THS720a battery pack.
customer_reviews.author: Mike Phillips

customer_reviews.title: Be warned: MADE IN CHINA
customer_reviews.text: These batteries are no longer made in Japan. Amazon replaced them with Chinese junk. If you think it makes no difference, go ahead and search Japanese vs Chinese batteries online. You’ll be surprised how low quality Chinese batteries are.
customer_reviews.author: Dripple

customer_reviews.title: Bad batch. Defective, cheap and unsafe
customer_reviews.text: Get what you pay for. Purchased these to go into kids walkie talkie. Inserted batteries correctly. Two walkie talkies worked no worries with these batteries . 3rd walkie talkie - the amazon batteries immediately started heating up to a burning hot temperature without being turned on. Heat could be felt through the battery cover. Removed hot batteries. Let device and batteries cool down. Inserted different brand batteries into third walkie talkie. Item works great and new batteries did not heat up. Suspect faulty batteries somehow internally shorted. Requested refund.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Biggest gripe.....NOT pre-charged as advertised
customer_reviews.text: UPDATE: After only a couple of recharging cycles, the majority of these batteries either will not take a charge, nor hold a charge more than overnight! THESE THINGS ARE TERRIBLE!!! ABSOLUTE JUNK!!! Besides the fact that these batteries were 2 days late arriving (Amazon Prime), my biggest gripe is, and the reason I purchased them, was the fact that they were advertised to come "Pre-Charged"......NOT!! EVERY SINGLE ONE WAS STONE DEAD! Have no idea how good or bad these batteries will be.....but I am sick and tired of products that advertise something, then don't deliver it! Hence, only a single star!
customer_reviews.author: EdCaffreyMS

customer_reviews.title: DISCHARGE capacity in  actual use twice what my ordinary NiMH are
customer_reviews.text: Amazon makes NO assertion that these are the sine qua non of NiMH batteries: Eneloops. But my usage reveals these babies run full power till they are DEAD! No doubt about when to recharge ;-) And I am getting twice the performance than ordinary NiMH's that I have had in service with the same device Observe the graph, my Amazon Basics batteries behave like the right hand curve. I thought I could,'t afford Eneloops but I am getting the smae performance form these Amazon Basics NiMH cells You can take that form the son of a batery chemist whgo during WW-2 worked at PR Mallory in Indianapolis and developed the Mercury battery needed for our radio-driven artillery proximity fuses.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Batteries catching fire
customer_reviews.text: Incredibly disappointing purchase. After recharging (and yes, I did it correctly), the batteries got extremely hot, emitted a bad smell and then started smoldering. Had to recycle the entire purchase. Would definitely not purchase again. Total waste of money.
customer_reviews.author: Christine Sublett

customer_reviews.title: Leaky, high failure rate
customer_reviews.text: In a package of 16, 1 was leaking when I first received the box and caused hand irritation. Assuming that it was I fluke, I continued to use. Three have failed to recharge. One leaks so badly that it ruined the Vermont LED candle (see photo). Unacceptable overall.
customer_reviews.author: J. J. Curry

customer_reviews.title: No good !
customer_reviews.text: These are terrible rechargeable batteries , they last for maybe 2 weeks before you need to recharge again after very moderate daily use. Then, my chargers indicates that some of the batteries are no good and will not except a charge , and thats right after the first use. So far , I l've lost an average of one to two batteries during the next recharge cycle. I have 3 different chargers and its happening on all 3 chargers , so its not because of the chargers I use. I also charge the batteries I buy before first use , simply because they are half dead when you receive them.
customer_reviews.author: Hungry Guy

customer_reviews.title: Poor performing batteries
customer_reviews.text: When the batteries were brand new they performed very well. I purchased the Bonai charger with these, so I'm not 100% certain that it's the fault of the charger or the batteries, but from the first time I recharged the batters onward, the batteries perform at a much lower level, and go dead very quickly. The charging voltage is 1.68vdc, so that seems like it should do the job of charging these batteries properly..
customer_reviews.author: Mark Shindler

customer_reviews.title: Not worth the money.
customer_reviews.text: Not sure if I got a defective batch but a week after we bought these AAs and AAAs we couldn't recharge some of them (they've never been recharged more than once since we received them). Now as more and more of them starting to die off, I'm starting to think there's a clear pattern that these are defective. Also, the ones I received do not match the colors shown in the pics. The ones we got are white and not green so I wonder if these are older batteries they're trying to offload.
customer_reviews.author: Matt H.

customer_reviews.title: Reliable Rechargeable Battery
customer_reviews.text: Purchased these rechargeable batteries to replace out C-Cell Alkaine Batteries. They are holding up well and after recharging a few times are are a much better value long term.
customer_reviews.author: Thea

customer_reviews.title: Dead on arrival
customer_reviews.text: I purchased the AA batteries because of the high rating of the battery. I placed one of these AA batteries in a clock and the clock worked for an hour. I wonder if these batteries are really worth the extra cost. I also purchased Tenergy batteries due to their low discharge rate and hope they are a better battery. These batteries needed charged right out of the package and wonder if there's a problem with high self discharge rate? Just a follow-up, these batteries are terrible for the heat of AZ. The charge doesn't last a month even in a analog clock. I would not recommend these batteries.
customer_reviews.author: nikboom

customer_reviews.title: 3 dead batteries out of 4? Come on Amazon.
customer_reviews.text: Purchased these AA batteries on April 2018. Used it for my son’s RC remote, and finally remote stopped working in February 2019. So first off is, why are these batteries, used on an RC remote, stopped working within less than a year? My son don’t use the RC that often btw. So, I went ahead and opened the remote, took out the batteries, have it recharged, since they are rechargeable batteries, and guess what, if you look on the photo taken, you noticed that only 1 out of 4 Amazon Basic batteries worked and is recharging. 1 out of 4 worked? Come on Amazon. Well, I guess I won’t be buying Amazon batteries anymore.
customer_reviews.author: AnakManis

customer_reviews.title: Clearances are not equal to Panasonic Eneloop NIHM AA batteries
customer_reviews.text: I gave these Amazon NIHM rechargeable batteries a lower mark based on the simple fact that they're circumference is larger than the Panasonic Eneloop AA batteries. Maybe my fault, but I tried to save a few bucks because these batteries give the impression that they are "Eneloop Clones". They have to be forced into my 2-way radio. They are also more difficult to remove. This is the main rationale for my lower marks. The Panasonic Eneloop AA NIMH rechargeable are worth the extra few bucks that they cost for me. I now suffer with buyer's remorse to save a few dollats.
customer_reviews.author: Tom

customer_reviews.title: Buy Sanyo instead. These don't last.
customer_reviews.text: I have 4 Eneloops that I'm still using after 10+ years and they STILL have more capacity (by far) than my Amazon Basics purchased two years ago. I use these intermittently in a digital camera, and find the AZ batteries get several photos in, but then peter out. My cells were made in Japan, but they are likely NOT the same chemistry as Eneloops; Sanyo would not well their top tier product to AZ... perhaps seconds, though. I would be even more wary of repurchasing is the cells are made in China.
customer_reviews.author: W. Higgins

customer_reviews.title: A good price for good quality rechargeables
customer_reviews.text: I love a good rechargeable battery. I hate to waste money on disposable batteries, especially for high drain items that burn through batteries every couple of weeks. I used these on a battery powered candle. Unfortunately, they didn't last as long as I would have liked. Less than a week on a 3 hour timer everyday. I also tried them in light up letters and they lasted a couple of weeks. That was definitely a more manageable amount of time. Overall, I would recommend these batteries for lighter duty work in toys or remote controls.
customer_reviews.author: Matt Devine

customer_reviews.title: 100% satisfied. Good batteries for less money than Panasonic Eneloops.
customer_reviews.text: These are way less money than the eneloops I have. Nevertheless these work well. Just time will tell how long they are lasting. Till now they have awesome performance. Just dont buy an amazon charger for these but buy an Panasonic smart charger since that one charges them individually. Use only Panasonic smart chargers for these batteries. However these can be reloaded only 1000 times while the more expensier Panasonic Eneloops can be reloaded up to 2100 times. I recommend. They work.
customer_reviews.author: G. Normalo

customer_reviews.title: Rusting after 2 months.
customer_reviews.text: I have had these batteries for about 2 months and my son keeps changing out our Xbox controller batteries daily because they are not lasting more than 24 hours after a full recharge. After closer inspection, almost all of them are rusting from thr inside out. They are not anywhere near water and we don't have a ton of humidity here so I can only imagine they are faulty. I cant return them anymore but I am hoping Amazon will read this review and contact me to replace them. We have never had a problem with them before now.
customer_reviews.author: Layn3

customer_reviews.title: Got the one made in Japan
customer_reviews.text: I ordered this Amazon Rechargeable battery on December 2019 (Black body with Green Ring on the positive terminal. An I can confirm that it’s Made in Japan. Even the packaging and instruction manual that came with it says so.
customer_reviews.author: whenicamearound

customer_reviews.title: I've had a high failure rate with these
customer_reviews.text: I've had a higher than expected failure rate with these batteries. I bought a bunch of them a couple of years ago and I have some that no longer accept a charge. People are saying these are rebranded versions of an expensive battery, but I haven't seen any proof and they certainly are getting a poorer rating over thousands of reviews. Over the span of 10 charges I've seen a 25% failure rate. I should be getting at least hundreds of charge cycles, not 5-10. Maybe I've been unlucky but the number of reviews on here seems to reinforce this data.
customer_reviews.author: A. Fabbri

customer_reviews.title: Made in China, don't last as long as envelop
customer_reviews.text: Was hoping the batteries are made by Japan so it's comparable with Envelop, unfortunately they are made in china, and the batteries don't last as long compare to Envelop
customer_reviews.author: WWC2

customer_reviews.title: Quality Control Concerns
customer_reviews.text: These are not the batteries you are looking for. They are wider than previous versions making installation difficult if not impossible. I have concerns over quality control as a number of the first batch I received had outer coverings to the battery that were already peeling. The replacement set I received were better in that regards but had a number of batteries that were DOA. Seek alternatives.
customer_reviews.author: Disneyfan78

customer_reviews.title: Trash Batteries.
customer_reviews.text: 2 Charges in and these things barely hold a charge anymore. I am extremely disappointed and will never buy them again. These thing used to be much better.
customer_reviews.author: cowforcow

customer_reviews.title: Great if you want to use them like a disposable
customer_reviews.text: Absolute junk batteries on longevity. I went all in and bought a large amount of these to get a good rechargeable rotation of all my devices. Every cycle through my devices I am getting a blinking red-light "bad cell" indicator on the charging dock for at least 1-2 batteries. At this rate I'll be able to celebrate the 1 year anniversary of my purchase by having none of these batteries left. Really frustrated by the performance of these (the first batteries started dying after 2 charges).
customer_reviews.author: Michael B.

customer_reviews.title: Not 1.5v AA's!
customer_reviews.text: These are 1.2v. It's like installing low batteries. They do not work well or very long in anything that has a motor or light. In some cases they do not physically fit because they are slightly larger. Not good for those 8-battery game cameras. These rechargables last days or weeks when regular batteries can last weeks and moths. Flashlights run dimmer from start and don't last. These are good for your remote controls and thats about all. The solution is to buy the 1.5v rechargeables and 1.5+v chargers. About $5 ea.
customer_reviews.author: Mark D.

customer_reviews.title: Battery won't charge
customer_reviews.text: I plugged all 4 batteries into the charger at the same time, and 3 finished charging at about the same time, but one battery won't charge. I have changed the charger that it was in, and it's been about 8 hours.
customer_reviews.author: EB

customer_reviews.title: I didn't get a chance to see how well these worked
customer_reviews.text: I installed 3 of these AAA batteries in a 3-in-1 flashlight that I have. It's a day/night light with a laser pointer. But after a short while I began to feel the metal flashlight getting warm. I opened it back up and found one of the batteries was extremely hot! So I tried to remove them as quickly as possible, and set them aside to cool down. I usually have a good experience with Amazon Basic items, so this was a surprise. Oh well, so needless to say, I requested a refund.
customer_reviews.author: Anthony Goncalves

customer_reviews.title: Charge lasts less and less!
customer_reviews.text: I purchased 12 of these batteries for my Christmas candles to keep from throwing so many batteries in the trash. While I didn't think rechargeable batteries would last as long as alkaline batteries I wasn't expecting them to last for less and less time with every charge. I spent $36 on 12 of these batteries and I'll be very lucky if they last for 2 Holiday seasons. I would buy Duracell or Energizer. They might cost more but I'm sure they'll last longer!
customer_reviews.author: paulaleg

customer_reviews.title: Not the good Japanese batteries anymore!
customer_reviews.text: Have bought these over the years and the 8 pack always contained the Japanese made version that have performed very well. The last purchase, which was a bit over a year ago contained the Chinese made batteries. I decided to give them a try. Now at little over a year later the Chinese made ones will not charge at all while the oldest of the Japanese made ones are still working fine. What's the point of "Green" options such as rechargeable batteries if they don't last very long? Total waste of natural resources and a waste of money.
customer_reviews.author: Math Mom

customer_reviews.title: Great price for rechargeable!
customer_reviews.text: We go through a lot of batteries in our household. I have a few rechargeable AA batteries but no AAA. I was looking on amazon for some AAA batteries and I picked these because they were cheaper than many of the other ones I was looking at, and I didn't notice right away that they were rechargeable! These arrived well packaged but without any instructions. I wasn't sure if these came changed or not, but they are! Happy to be slowly adding to my rechargeable battery stash.
customer_reviews.author: jennys

customer_reviews.title: Won't last for more than 10 to 15 recharges
customer_reviews.text: Brought these mainlynfor kids toys. They will not charge after 10 or 15 recharges. This is not just for one or few batteries, I am having the same issue with all of them. I tried both AA and AAA as I thought that they might be a deal due to lower price. The results are the same for all of them. Enelope and Duracell are still going strong even after multiple recharges. They are not worth it. Two stars as they worked for approximately 6 months. The ones I bought were white color and not the green ones they are currently selling.
customer_reviews.author: AK

customer_reviews.title: "AA" AND "AAA"?  FORGET IT
customer_reviews.text: Somebody screwed up, and it wasn't me when I ordered this item. This recharge unit will certainly NOT ACCEPT "AAA" batteries of any sort!. I ordered this unit along with a pack that would fit this contraption, ... the batteries didn't fir, or come close to fitting this unit. I received "Amazon Choice" triple 'A', ... ithat were within the flashlights I purchased! So now I'm purchasing "AAA" batteries on my own, and this "recharger" is sitting here upon my computer desk, collecting dust. GUess I'll have to purchase some 'recharge "AA" in order to make everything work. Go to your local Wal-Mart or Ace-Hardware, and purchase the unit as a whole item. You'll save in your frustration!
customer_reviews.author: Peasaint

customer_reviews.title: So far, they work fine
customer_reviews.text: I've tried them in my 3rd party flash, with good results. HINT! Just NEVER carry the batteries loose in your purse or pocket! I took a photography class from a fellow that did. He told us his batteries and loose change, keys, etc. got shorted together and burned a hole in his pants! He probably learned a whole new definition of the term "hot rocks! Amazon''s batteries were once at a better price point than Eneloop batteries, which I have used with satisfaction for years. Apparently, no longer. I bought this set of Amazon's equivalent batteries"just to see" , but may go back to the Eneloops for my next purchase because of my good experiences with them. Time will tell.
customer_reviews.author: humminboid

customer_reviews.title: Average to somewhat below average rechargeable AAA batteries.
customer_reviews.text: As an alternative to RAYOVAC rechargeable AAA batteries, which I feel are in the same class, I tried the AmazonBasics AAA Rechargeable Batteries. The application is a small motion-sensing light, requiring 4 AAA batteries, that is positioned on a stair-rail. While the light doesn't require a large amount of instantaneous output from the batteries, it demands an on/off function that cycles quite frequently. The AmazonBasics performed just below that of the RAYOVAC batteries and required recharging two to three days earlier. The AmazonBasic batteries rate at average to just below average. For the price, and in the long run, I would recommend purchasing something like the RAYOVAC or up to one level to the Energizer Recharge Universal.
customer_reviews.author: Denice C.

product_meta.title: AmazonBasics AA Rechargeable Batteries (2000 mAh), Pre-charged - Pack of 8
product_meta.description: Size:AA 8 Pack| Style:BatteriesAmazonBasics brings you everyday items at a great value. An Amazon Brand.
feature_bullets: One 8-pack of pre-charged AA rechargeable batteries (2000 mAh), ideal for digital cameras, remote controls, toys, and more
Long battery life; extremely gradual self-discharge; maintains 80% capacity for 24 months
Comes pre-charged and ready to use; can be recharged 1000 times with minimal power loss
Ships in Certified Frustration-Free Packaging; recyclable; backed by an AmazonBasics 1-year limited warranty
The batteries can be recycled when they no longer hold a charge; to find a recycling location near you, simply copy/paste this link into your browser: call2recycle.org/locator/

specifications.Customer Reviews: 4.4 out of 5 stars72,855 ratings4.4 out of 5 stars
